text: Family Member: But it is holding him, right? Doctor: Some parts of it but I think we have to think about adding something else to the mix here or stopping it. And I just want to double-check. You’re still taking Xtandi? Okay, and are you alternating like number of pills per day or are you just - Patient: Four a day. Doctor: Okay, so you know you don’t have much room to go from that because that’s the max dose. But when you break through from the bone scan it tells me it’s really not working. The stuff that’s being not - you know it’s not in your liver or anything else. Like it’s just still in the bone and you’ve got pain actually suggests we could try a different treatment called Xofigo. And I mentioned this like a while back. This is that radium stuff that Marie Curie discovered many years ago. I don’t know if you guys remember that from elementary school. But it basically kills, you know, cancer in the bones. Well in her case she died because she was carrying too much of it in her pocket. But in patients, it’s now in legit treatment for men with prostate cancer that has gone to bone. Family Member: Does that look - something you inject, like a pill or capsule or something? Doctor: No, it’s actually, they put an I.V. in you and it comes in a – it’s a liquid. It’s like liquid radiation, and they draw it up and then they just inject it in you. It’s like you know, it’s like in, in over a minute, and it’s once a month for six months. The person that is the expert is the radiation oncology doctor, and that person knows how to regulate obviously radiation. This is a form of radiation. Family Member: Is that what they did to him before when he went down there? They - Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Where the pain, where the pain was? Doctor: Uh hum, well there, they radiated you from the outside. You laid down and they beamed it to you, right. This is internal. So when they push it in your bloodstream it goes all around and it lands in the area of the bone that has the cancer. Family Member: Is there side effects? Doctor: Oh yeah, there’s always side effects. Because it’s radiation, some of the side effects could be you know reduced or lower amounts of blood cells in your system, so people could get low white cells, red cells, platelets. Those are your three guys that I always watch out for and in some people, it’s a pretty big dip and you don’t come back. Very rare, but it’s a possibility. Family Member: What do you mean a dip?

text: Patient: So I’ll only be in Texas for now long? Doctor: One or two days. Patient: A couple of days? Doctor: Yeah. The scan takes literally two hours. Patient: Stay, stay in the hospital or is-? Doctor: No. I think they put you in a hotel. Patient: Put you in a hotel? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Hum. And that’s in what town? Doctor: No. I’ll tell you. I can find out. (Laughs) Patient: There’s no way, there’s no way of getting that? What medicine is that they give you for it? Doctor: It’s not the medicine. It’s the scan that is a specific one. That scanner is not available here or around here.

text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the purpose of this therapy, which we also call bipolar androgen therapy or BAT for short. We call it bipolar, not because it makes the patients bipolar. Doctor: But because we reach two extreme opposite levels of testosterone, opposite poles. Patient: Excuse me; does it have to be Lupron or it could be another hormone? Doctor: It has to be an injectable testosterone-lowering medication. It doesn’t have to be specifically Lupron. It can be any of the injectable hormone therapies. It cannot be an oral hormone therapy. Patient: Right. Okay, okay. Doctor: And typically it’s one of the hormone therapies that’s injected either every three months or every six months. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the reason I’m mentioning that is because a lot of patients do want to go on this therapy without being on the Lupron at the same time or a similar drug. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And the way that the trial is designed, if you give the testosterone without concurrently at the same time, suppressing the testosterone as well, then you don’t achieve these opposites between very high and very low levels. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: What happens is over time is the testosterone just keeps increasing and increasing and increasing, and eventually it will begin to feed the cancer, at least in theory.

We call it bipolar, not because it makes the patients bipolar. Doctor: But because we reach two extreme opposite levels of testosterone, opposite poles. It can be any of the injectable hormone therapies. It cannot be an oral hormone therapy. Patient: Right. Okay, okay. Doctor: And typically it’s one of the hormone therapies that’s injected either every three months or every six months. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the reason I’m mentioning that is because a lot of patients do want to go on this therapy without being on the Lupron at the same time or a similar drug. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And the way that the trial is designed, if you give the testosterone without concurrently at the same time, suppressing the testosterone as well, then you don’t achieve these opposites between very high and very low levels. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: What happens is over time is the testosterone just keeps increasing and increasing and increasing, and eventually it will begin to feed the cancer, at least in theory.

text: Patient: If it’s so good, why don’t they, why does it take so long in the U.S. then to get these? Doctor: So, in Germany, and Australia, I know they’re also doing it in Australia. I know it’s a little farther for you- Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Uh in Germany they have a law that if the doctor thinks something is beneficial it doesn’t have to be you know like you know in America, FDA approved. So the FDA, the bar is show me it makes people live longer. It’s a pretty high bar. Because that requires a lot of patients, a lot time. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but at the end of the day, you feel really confident that what I’m giving you could help. Patient: Right. I got it. Doctor: What they are allowed to do there is use the material as long as they don’t try to sell it outside their hospital or use it outside the hospital, they’re allowed to do it. And the material they’re using is kind of an off-the-shelf thing where they could buy it, make it on site. Uh in the U.S. what’s gotten problematic is I think we’re on the third company now that’s tried to develop this. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: The first two companies kind of went under. It’s a little bit complicated with the drug involved because it’s radioactive. You’ve got to have a whole infrastructure. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: To make sure the radiation is here on Tuesday when you’re here. It’s not like you just go over to the pharmacy and grab it because there’s all that stuff.

Doctor: To make sure the radiation is here on Tuesday when you’re here. It’s not like you just go over to the pharmacy and grab it because there’s all that stuff.

text: Family Member: So he won’t get; will he – does he need nausea medication for this drug or anything? Doctor: Typically not; obviously we can, oh you know, he’s such a typical guy. But yes, Dr. ___ can prescribe that because he has a set thing because this is his program to run. So I’m just hovering nearby. Family Member: I think he was the one that actually diagnosed you with cancer when I told him to do the bone scan. Doctor: Oh my gosh! That’s been a long time then. Patient: Yes. Family Member: Yeah, because he was just going to start him on radiation and I go well - Doctor: No, he saw Dr. ___ in O____ when I was there many moons ago. Family Member: Because I told him, “His dad suffered, died from prostate cancer, could you at least do a scan on him and make sure he doesn’t have bone cancer?” And they did. Doctor: Yeah. And poof! Family Member: And bam, it showed up! Doctor: Told you you were weird. Patient: So then, yes, so then it was at that point that I went to ___ for a consult. Family Member: Uh hum, yeah.

text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I think like taking a globe and a string or something and see. Patient: Yeah. I didn’t understand why- Doctor: I don’t quite understand how it’s shorter, but it’s shorter. Doctor: There’s a part over Canada where you cross, there’s like a big bay, I think the jet stream. It gets real choppy there. You get a lot of turbulence. I always know- Family Member: Yeah. We did. Doctor: And one time, I don’t know where I was, but I remember looking out the window. I could see Greenland. Doctor: I could see actually. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: We have done a handful of men before, and the handful of men seemed to have their PSA drop for awhile. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But, it’s not the mega excitement in prostate cancer, uh, that we see with the other tumors that you hear on the news with Jimmy Carter and all of those kinds of – Patient: Right, right. Doctor: Um, it can possibly benefit people for awhile. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, we’ve amended it and added a new cohort, so another group of men. But, these are men that they’re last therapy, or their willingness to stay on Enzalutamide, because there’s one group, uh, that showed that maybe if you use Enzalutamide and immune therapy, you get a better response (chuckles) Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, we’re testing a group of men, uh, uh, with that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay.

text: Patient: No chemo drug, though? Doctor: It is more of a natural product, biologic drug that on, um, in animals and in cell lines looks active against prostate cancer. And, so, now they’re escalating the dose of this natural product. Um. Family Member: Is that, uh, a stem cell or cell therapy or is it a -- Doctor: No, it comes like from a, I--I’d have to look. Whether it comes from a seed cucumber or-- Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Or a pine co—Oh, it’s—I’d have to look it up. But, it’s, it’s a natural thing that, that, they have --- Patient: It’s organic medicine. Doctor: Right. You know, we’ve done studies with pomegranates and muscadine grapes, and it sort of extends to that sort of area. Uh, but this again is, uh, experimental. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um. So, in that study, we’re looking at how you tolerate it. Uh, what’s the safe dose. Ah, and then, you know, we monitor your disease; that if it’s not getting better, then we move on. If it is improving or not - stable, you can stay with that treatment. Patient: Okay. Family Member: It’s a phase one. How long does the phase one run for? Uh, because I’m wondering if there are subsequent phases, um but Doctor: So, typically, we treat three men at a one-dose level.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
